phrase.item: In books they say that a child is born from its mother after nine months, nine days, nine hours, nine seconds.
Only the woman knows based on her state [of being] when the child was conceived.
But not all women know exactly.
When the delivery is approaching the woman tells another woman that her contractions have begun.
Then we make all of the men leave the house.
On the ground or in the cavity in front of the hearth (oven) we put down sand or soft soil or pounded manure so that the child doesn't get hurt.
When the child falls on the soft ground or sand, the mother or another woman staying with her cuts the umbilical cord with scissors.
We pulverize charcoal and we coat the navel with it which we ligature with a string.
We put the placenta of the new mother in something and the woman who took care of her takes it far and throws it away.
This container can no longer be used
and the woman who helped her washes herself and her clothes as well.
Next we bathe the child, we put a diaper on him/her and inside the diaper we put pounded (ground) manure.
Then we also put pounded (ground) manure in the pants of the new mother so that blood doesn't flow.
We tie the pants' ends so that the manure doesn't escape (fall out.)
We set up the woman to sleep separately for three days.
The third day we remove the manure from her pants and she gets up.
Up until now we put butter in the mouth of the newborn child.
The third or seventh day, when the woman (mother) washes herself, we place the child in a cradle and the mother gives him/her breastmilk.
And if there are no other women aside from her in the home, after seven days she approaches the hearth (oven) and prepares food.
Otherwise generally she isn't supposed to approach the oven for forty days because she is impure.
The husband also does not sleep with the wife for forty days.
Some people abstain for seven days, and even sometimes forty days, from eating in the home.
Here the only way is to slaughter a chicken, a rooster or to make the blood flow from the ear of a sheep.
Generally up until we've beheaded a sheep in the home of the new mother, this home is considered impure.
When the sun sets, at night or during the evening, we mustn't enter the home of the new mother.
If we arrive a bit early, we shout (call) through the doors (gates).
When the door is opened we throw fire.
The person passes over fire or embers when entering so that a dive or a djinn (evil spirits) do not come inside.
The day that we enter, we organize a meal and we sing songs.
But at night for forty days we mustn't approach the newborn.
Women most often give birth at night or in the morning.
This is why we say that as long as we haven't brought in the livestock for the night, man neither dies nor is born.
